dayInfo.description: SANTIAGO DE CHILE – Welcome to Chile! Your transfer will be waiting for you to take you to your hotel in the city. Depending on when your flight arrives, you will have free time during the day and evening to rest or explore the city a bit on your own. If you choose to go out and explore, here are some of our suggestions for points of interest: 1. Hike up Cerro Santa Lucia 2. Take the funicular or cable car to the summit of Cerro San Cristobal 3. Visit local museums: - Museum of Memory and Human Rights. - National Museum of Natural History. - Chilean Museum of Pre-Columbian Arts. - Museum of Visual Arts. - Archaeological Museum of Santiago. 4. Visit La Chascona, Pablo Neruda's Santiago home. 5. Visit the Arts & Crafts village at Pueblito los Dominicos. 6. Dine at some of Santiago’s top restaurants. .

SANTIAGO DE CHILE – EASTER ISLAND – OPTIONAL STARGAZING EXPERIENCE - In the morning, you’ll be picked up from your hotel and taken to the Santiago Airport for your flight to Easter Island, which takes about five hours. Upon arrival, you'll be taken to your hotel, where you can take the opportunity to rest and refresh yourself. In the afternoon, you'll have time to explore the island until your optional evening activity. Once night falls, opt to take a trip through history to discover astronomical concepts, Polynesian settlement and travel history, and Rapa Nui archeoastronomy. On one of the world's most isolated islands, you'll visit some of the old observatory sites to marvel at the stunning night sky and see stars and constellations that are only visible in the Southern Hemisphere. (Note that this activity is not included in the quoted price.)

EASTER ISLAND – PRIVATE FULL DAY TOUR: IN SEARCH OF THE BIRDMAN CULT On the third day of your adventure, delve into some of Easter Island's most captivating and historically significant sites. Begin your day with a hearty breakfast, followed by a climb to the clifftop village of Orongo. Uncover the intriguing tale of the Birdman Cult and the annual competition held at Tangata Manu. Your journey will then lead you to Rano Kau, the island's largest volcano crater, boasting its own miniature ecosystem. Continue inland to witness the awe-inspiring Ahu A'kivi platform, adorned with seven renowned moai gazing out to sea. Concluding the day's exploration, visit Puna Pau, the quarry where the iconic topknots of the moai were crafted.

EASTER ISLAND – PRIVATE FULL DAY TOUR: MOAI MONUMENTS – Embark on a journey to uncover the enigmatic secrets of the colossal moai sculptures that define the iconic allure of Easter Island. Immerse yourself in the captivating history and culture of the Rapa Nui people, delving into the intricacies of how and why these statues were crafted, and the remarkable process of carving and transporting the massive stones to their designated platforms. As part of the tour, your exploration will take you to Ahu Akahanga, where fallen moai bear witness to rebels who opposed their ancestors' traditions. Witness the restoration efforts at Ahu Tongariki, where 15 statues stand as guardians of the land. Visit Te Pito Kura to unravel the mysteries surrounding the magnetic stone and indulge in the serene beauty of Anakena Beach.

EASTER ISLAND - HALF DAY TOUR: TONGARIKI SUNRISE - SANTIAGO – Watching the dawn behind fifteen moai sculptures is the ideal way to end your time on Easter Island, and you can take those memories with you. You'll then be picked up to go to the airport for your return flight to Santiago. You'll have the rest of the day to explore Santiago on your own.

HALF DAY CITY TOUR SANTIAGO – A BITE OF SANTIAGO On this insider city tour, you'll get to learn more about Santiago today. We'll go to the historic city center, where you can learn about the past of the area and of Chile, sample local food by going to the markets, where you can see how the dishes are made and tried, see the most well-known sights in the area, and much more. You'll have earned the title of "Santiaguino" at the end of the journey! You'll have the remainder of the day free after the trip to further explore or relax at your hotel.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE - VALPARAISO & CASABLANCA WINE VALLEY – Today, we head out of Santiago towards the coast. We’ll start with a walking tour in Valparaiso, a bohemian city renowned for its counterculture atmosphere, colorful homes, distinctive regional architecture, brilliant street art, and hill-climbing funicular lifts. We'll pause to sample some of the extremely tasty and fresh food the area has to offer. Then, as we make our way back toward Santiago, we'll stop in the famed Casablanca wine valley, known for its delicious red and white wines. We'll go to Emiliana, one of the most prestigious vineyards in the region that specializes in organic and biodynamic wines. We'll have a tour of the vineyard and winery and taste some of their wines with some cheese or chocolate from the area before returning to Santiago for the evening.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE - CALAMA - SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA – OPTIONAL STARGAZING EXPERIENCE At a pre-arranged time, you’ll be picked up from your Santiago hotel and taken to the airport for your flight to Calama in the Atacama Desert. The city of Calama has the nearest airport to San Pedro de Atacama, the hub for our Atacama adventures. Upon arrival in Calama, one of our representatives will pick you up from the airport for the drive to San Pedro. Along the way, you’ll pass spectacular desert scenery like endless plains and high-altitude mountains streaked with colourful stones and sand. When we arrive in San Pedro, you’ll be dropped off at your hotel to get settled and enjoy the evening at your leisure. San Pedro is a great town to discover on foot, full of cobblestoned streets lined with adobe buildings that house local restaurants and stores. As the night falls, you'll have the opportunity to partake in an optional stargazing tour, contingent upon favourable climatic conditions and the lunar cycle. Immerse yourself in the mesmerizing expanse of some of the Earth's clearest night skies in the Atacama Desert. Gain insights into the constellations, marvel at the intricate details of planets through telescopes, and delve into the Andean cosmovision, learning about the significance of celestial objects in indigenous worldviews. (Note that this activity is not included in the quoted price.)

SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA: ALTIPLANIC LAGOONS AND WOOL MANUFACTURING PROCESS OF SOCAIRE – Today, we’ll drive up to the high-altitude plateau to discover some of the remarkable landscapes that this desert is famous for. Along the drive, you may also have the chance to see local wildlife. After roughly an hour, we’ll arrive at the enchanting Miscanti and Miñiques lagoons, which sit over 13,000 feet (4,000 meters) above sea level. We’ll then drive to Socaire, a traditional adobe village of just 360 inhabitants. After lunch at a local restaurant, we’ll visit some of the village’s weavers, where we’ll get to learn about and observe their knitting. After this class, we’ll return to San Pedro for a free evening. Please note: Activities may vary or have to be changed due to bad weather, unsafe road conditions, etc. Should a cancellation take place, an alternate activity/excursion will be arranged.

SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA – FULL DAY TOUR: TATIO GEYSER, MACHUCA, & PUTANA WETLANDS – Today, we’ll visit the famous Tatio Geysers, which at 14,173 feet (4,320 meters) above sea level are the highest in the world! At around 6:30 am, we’ll drive to the village of Machuca on the way to the geysers, where we’ll pause to explore the ancient adobe dwellings and historic church. Most visitors stop here after coming back from the geysers, so we’ll have the place all to ourselves. We'll then continue on to the Putana wetlands, located next to the Putana Volcano. After a photo op there, we’ll head to the geyser field, which we will explore walking along the marked paths that weave through the geysers, watching them erupt and fill the air with steam. You also have the option of taking a quick soak in the river next to the geysers (don’t worry: it’s not too hot!)! After exploring the area, we’ll return to San Pedro around 2:00 pm and you’ll have the rest of the day to relax or explore.

SAN PEDRO DE ATACAMA - HALF DAY TOUR: MOON VALLEY – SANTIAGO We'll leave early in the morning to travel to the Valle de la Luna (The Moon Valley), one of the most well-known locations in the Atacama. We'll have breakfast when we get there and and take in the morning hues of this incredible scene. Then we'll get a chance to see a "Ayllu," a prehistoric communal structure built by the Atacameos or Lickan-Antay people. After that, we'll head back to San Pedro about 11:30, at which point your driver will pick you up from your hotel and transport you to Calama's Airport in time for your flight back to Santiago. When you arrive in Santiago, a representative will be waiting to drive you to your hotel. The rest of the day will be yours to enjoy at your leisure.
SANTIAGO – On your final day, you’ll be picked up from your hotel at a pre-arranged time and taken to the airport in Santiago for your departure flight. Safe travels!

tourName: Highlights of Chile tailor made holiday
generalInfo:

tourName: Patagonia kayaking holiday
generalInfo:
FROM CHILEAN WINERIES TO THE SAN RAFAEL GLACIER
Join us for a trip to incredible Coastal Patagonia! This tour allows you to experience quality while exploring the beautiful outer islands of southern Chile. We will experience the best of what Chile has to offer in a mothership style sea kayaking tour: wine, wildlife and wilderness paired with sea kayaking in one of the most stunning places on earth, all from the comfort and convenience of our personal expedition ship.

The coast of Chile stretches for over 4300 kilometres, providing endless opportunities for kayakers. The region we have chosen for our tours is considered Northern Patagonia and is part of the Aysen Region. Most people think that the southernmost portion of Chile (Southern Patagonia) is the most rugged and wild, but think again. We will take you into difficult to access areas with stunning landscapes, abundant wildlife, hot springs and glaciers dropping into the sea, all while enjoying safety and service you have come to expect.

We’ve crafted this trip to take in most of the highlights that we’ve discovered over the past 8 years of traveling to the area, and feel that it is an excellent and in-depth introduction to the area. Some of the top selections include paddling in beautiful and pristine Traiguén and Goñi Islands finding traces of the original inhabitants of the area among small islands of the archipelago, viewing abundant wildlife, soaking in remote hot springs, basking in the immensity of the San Rafael Glacier and taking in a traditional asado (barbecue) at a remote estancia – all among the backdrop of volcanoes and mountains.

This trip is suitable for all ages and ability levels. Participate in our activities as much or as little as you want while experiencing some of the most remote parts of Patagonia.

Everything is included in the tour cost from the time you arrive in Santiago until the last day of the tour. All you need is a sense of adventure and possibly a camera to catch the incredible beauty of area so that your friends will believe you when you try to describe this wild and wonderful place to them upon your return home.

The tour starts in Santiago and enjoy one day of touring and wine tastings in Chile’s fantastic and plentiful wine producing regions. On our second day we travel to Patagonia via a short regional flight. We will then meet our floating home, the 57-foot motor vessel called the Noctiluca. From here the world is our oyster as we explore this incredible coast line.

dayInfo.description: The day prior to our tour start. Depart your home for Santiago, Chile.

One or both of your guides will meet you at the international airport Santiago, Chile, wearing their company t-shirts. The afternoon is yours to explore the neighbourhood and city. Depending on how you are feeling after checking into the hotel and freshening up, you may be interested in a walk through some of the local parks & around the general area. If you prefer, please enjoy a nap or a quiet afternoon at the hotel. That evening we will all meet at the hotel and head out for a welcome dinner at one of our favourite Chilean establishments. (Please note, expenses on this day, other than the airport pickup, hotel and dinner, are not included in the tour cost). Then it’s time for a good night’s sleep.

After a hearty breakfast we will head out of the city to the beautiful Casablanca Valley to visit some of the best wineries in Chile. The journey through the Valley begins our encounter with some of the many different types of landscapes that we are about to experience over the rest of our journey. Here we will visit some boutique wineries as well as some of the well-known establishments for tastings and tours of their wine production. Of course there will be time for you to purchase a bottle or two to take home. We will return to the city in time for dinner at one of our favourite restaurants and will dine under the stars while enjoying the nightlife of the Chilean streets.

Morning will come early, but the excitement of the journey to come will help with our wake-up call. After a continental breakfast, we will transfer to the Santiago airport for our flight to Balmaceda airport. A 3-hour flight later, we will arrive in Patagonia! We will then drive an hour through beautiful rolling hills and past waterfalls to meet our mothership, the beautiful Noctiluca. The “Noctiluca” is a 57-foot motor yacht named after the luminous plankton that abounds in Patagonian waters (what we would call bioluminescence). Once all settled aboard, the captain will give us a safety briefing and we will enjoy dinner while watching the sun sink behind the islands as we motor out of the Aisen Fjord and Paso Casma. That night we will anchor in beautiful Chiva Cove (apx 60 nautical miles covered by boat). THE KAYAK PATAGONIA ADVENTURE BEGINS Please note that while this Patagonian coastline is absolutely stunning, it can be quite exposed to wind in certain areas so we have to split our paddling with motoring in order to get to some of the remote places to paddle. Both the paddling portion and the motoring portion of this trip are weather dependent, so the following itinerary is simply a guideline, but will likely need to be flexible to work with nature.

There are so many places to explore in this region it is hard to say exactly where to begin our paddling, but the many small islets of Isla Traiguén and its bird colonies are a likely starting point. Paddling in the area around Isla Goñi we’ll get a sense of a Patagonian landscape that is more often found even further south: low scrub vegetation with only a few trees near the shoreline, evidence of the harsh climate of the region. Here there are also signs of the original inhabitants of the islands, the Chonos people, in the form of shell middens (mounds of shell material deposited over many years from harvesting and consuming mussels and clams).

From Isla Goñi we head south again through Estero Elefantes to the entrance of San Rafael Lagoon. Here we will gather ancient ice for a toast to the imposing icebergs of the lagoon. That afternoon we will take an excursion by zodiac to the beaches and streams near the glacier.

Today we will explore the San Rafael Lagoon. We will have lunch near the glacier, surrounded by icebergs. We will carefully navigate our way by kayak through the icebergs to visit the region’s various beaches and islets. That evening we will anchor at Port Lepardo at the entrance of the lagoon. While we eat dinner we will listen for the tell-tale cracking sounds of the calving glacier in the distance.

Today we motor to the estancia (ranch) owned by our Captain Robin Westcott. Estancia Quitralco is a private ranch which covers many square kilometers and offers us the chance to spend the afternoon exploring the river by kayak, fly fishing and/or trekking on the property. We will finish off our day with an authentic gaucho lamb asado (or BBQ). The taste of fresh lamb and vegetables slow-roasted over an open fire enjoyed under the vast Patagonian sky is second to none. This meal of course will be accompanied by a great selection of Chilean wine and beer and vegetables picked fresh from the garden on-site. Is this heaven on earth?

Departing from Quitralco we will set sail for nearby hot springs. Discovered by our Captain’s family decades ago, this secluded and private location offers some luxurious soaking while taking in a fabulous view down the fiord. We will spend the remainder of the day navigating through small channels, ideal for dolphins and encounters with other wildlife. That night we spend anchored in Puerto Lynch.

We will get an extra early start this morning in order to reach the sheltered waters of Gato Cove in plenty of time to enjoy kayaking in Cinco Hermanas (Five Sisters) National Park. The scenery here will not disappoint. After exploring these beautiful islands we will motor to our final anchorage of the trip. Dinner on board will once again leave our taste buds truly satisfied and our bellies full. Really, could life get any better?

Sadly, this will be our last day on our floating home. We will get an early start to ensure we arrive back to Puerto Aisen in time to transfer back to the Balmaceda Airport in time to catch a flight back to Santiago that evening. If you are pressed for time, it may be possible to catch an international flight this evening (check with the office for details). The rest of the group will enjoy one last farewell dinner together in Santiago. Hotel this last night is included in the tour cost.

This is your last day in Santiago. After breakfast at the hotel you will say goodbye to your guides. You are welcome to explore the city on your own, perhaps heading to a local market for some souvenir shopping before flights that evening. Most international flights leave late in the day. We will arrange pickups and ensure you get to the airport safely.

tourName: Patagonia self drive holiday, 24 days
generalInfo:
Spend three and a half weeks, immersed in Patagonia’s wild beauty on an unforgettable self-drive through Chile’s remote Aysen region. This journey is designed for slow, meaningful travel, allowing time to connect with local life and appreciate Patagonia’s little-known landscapes without the rush.

Begin in the capital Santiago, before flying south to the Aysen region where your car-hire awaits. From there, traverse the iconic Carretera Austral (Austral Road), discovering a region of hanging glaciers, lenga forest, pristine rivers and raw wilderness. Kayak the Marble caves, Ice trek Exploradores Glacier, raft the rapids of Baker River and explore the rugged beauty of Patagonia's national parks. End your Slow Patagonia itinerary in Puerto Varas, a picturesque lakeside town in Chile’s southern Lake District, where German heritage meets breathtaking natural beauty.

Excursions are small-group tours, led by expert local guides. Accommodation has been hand-picked by us to ensure a comfortable and enriching experience. Along the Austral region, accommodation is a simple but welcoming base to explore the area. This trip can be tailored to your interests, so let us know your preferences.

dayInfo.description: Santiago: Welcome to Chile’s capital Santiago. Upon arrival, settle into your eco-boutique hotel in upscale Vitacura, a neighbourhood renowned for its leafy-lined streets and sophisticated charm.

Puerto Rio Tranquilo: Fly south to Balmaceda and, on arrival, collect your car-hire to begin your journey along the Carretera Austral. Drive approximately 3.5 hours through dramatic Patagonian scenery to reach your hotel in Puerto Rio Tranquilo, your base for the next three nights. Over the coming days, explore with expert local guides. One day, kayak through the striking Marble Caves, where its dazzling marble formations reflect off the waters of Lake General Carrera. The next, strap on crampons for an unforgettable ice trek across the Exploradores Glacier.

Baker River: Continue south along the Carretera Austral along the western shore of General Carrera Lake before entering the Chacabuco Valley, an area shaped by conservation projects and rewilding. Embark on a thrilling rafting adventure down the Baker River, the most powerful river in Chile, surrounded by dramatic landscapes.

Caleta Tortel: Drive through dense forests, rushing rivers and dramatic mountain scenery to reach the stilted village of Caleta Tortel. Explore its maze of cypress-plank boardwalks on foot. One highlight is visiting the La Isla de los Muertos (The Island of the Dead,) where thirty-three cypress crosses stand shrouded in mystery, discovered only in 1950, hidden deep within the vegetation.

General Carrera Lake: Drive approximately 3.5 hours north to your cozy, secluded ecolodge nestled on the banks of General Carrera Lake. In the afternoon, explore self-guided trails through native forest in the lodge’s private reserve.

Coyhaique: Continue north to the capital of the Aysen region. The drive is long and remote taking roughly 5-8 hours along windy scenic roads that pass dramatic mountain landscapes, fjords and temperate forest. Overnight in Coyhaique, explore its main square or if time permits visit the nearby Cerro Castillo National reserve.

Puyuhuapi: From Coyhaique, drive through Andean foothills, lush forests and winding rivers to the small village of Puyuhaupi. Puyuhaupi, is well known for its natural hot springs, fjord access, and gateway to Queulat National Park, home to the famous hanging glacier. During your stay, enjoy independent exploration of the national park’s hiking trails. We recommend hiking Sendero Laguna Tempanos and Mirador Ventisquero Colgante Trail (to see the Hanging Glacier).

Futaleufú: Continue to the adventure hub of Futaleufú, a remote and scenic drive that typically takes around six hours. During your stay, experience the adrenaline rush of world-class whitewater rafting on the wildest rapids of the Futaleufú River. If time permits, hike, fly-fish or horse-back ride amid dramatic mountain scenery.

Caleta Gonzalo: Journey southwest to Pumalin National Park, one of the world’s most successful private conservation projects. Stay in a remote lodge with access to hiking trails, kayaking and wildlife watching. During your stay, choose from several spectacular hiking trails in the park, including hikes to Chaitén Volcano, hidden waterfalls, and ancient alerce forest.

Hornopirén: Board the Naviera Austral ferry for an unforgettable voyage through Patagonian fjords. Glide past untouched rainforest and snow-capped peaks as you make your way north to Hornopirén, where you will spend the night.

Puerto Varas: Complete your self-drive journey as you drive from Hornopiren to Puerto Varas: a charming lakeside town with stunning views of Osorno Volcano across Lake Llanquihue. Explore the beauty of the area at your own pace. Venture into Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park and visit Petrohué Falls, ascend the slopes of Osorno or take a day trip to nearby Chiloé and discover the islands unique and mythical culture.

Santiago: Say goodbye to Patagonia, drop off your car-hire and fly north to Santiago, where you’ll spend one final night before heading home. If you would like to make the most of your time in the capital, we can arrange a guided city tour or recommend some wonderful places to eat- just let us know your preferences.

tourName: Patagonian photography tour
placesVisited: Photography holiday in Torres del Paine National Park, Punta Arenas, Stay at Eco Camp Patagonia, Patagonian wildlife watching
generalInfo:
This Patagonian photography is also a spectacular wildlife holiday in Torres del Paine National Park. Because not only will you be travelling with a professional nature and wildlife photographer, but also with expert wildlife trackers to help you find the wildest of ways through the park. A fixed date holiday, your guide and teacher is Diego Araya who, as well as publishing Patagonia 237, a big format coffee table book financed by Nikon Chile, is an experienced adventure guide.

Eco Camp Patagonia is an award winning accommodation where you stay in luxury geodesic domes. They have a minimal environmental footprint in this precious landscape, while also providing comforts such as hot showers, electricity and fine food. And during the day, you will get out into the park to explore its extraordinary geology, catch the light from magnificent sunrises or sunsets, and enjoy its diverse landscapes, home to a wonderful array of wildlife.

There are 26 species of mammal in Torres del Paine National Park, including the South Andean deer, the elusive puma and the guanaco. Keep a look out for superb birdlife, including the celebrated condor.

dayInfo.description: Travel from Punta Arenas, Puerto Natales or Calafate to Torres del Paine National Park. The trip begins with you being picked up from your hotel in Punta Arenas or Punta Arenas airport in the morning and driven to EcoCamp Patagonia, located in the world-famous Torres del Paine National Park. Alternatively you can start your trip in El Calafate / Argentina. En route we make a couple of stops - First in Puerto Natales, a small, lively town on the shores of "Seno de Ultima Esperanza", where we enjoy a hearty local lunch, and second at Cueva de Milodon, a massive prehistoric cave where the remains of a giant ground sloth were discovered in the 1890’s. The whole journey is very scenic, with plenty of wild birds and wonderful landscapes to be seen. The day ends with our arrival and overnight stay at EcoCamp Patagonia, nestled in the heart of the park with a view of the Torres. During summer the sun sets around 11pm, so upon arrival there's plenty of light to admire the Patagonian steppe with its guanacos and snow-peaked mountain horizon. After dinner our guide, Diego, gives a briefing on the upcoming days and the wildlife we’ll be seeing. (L,D)

Early mornings and late nights spent photographing in the national park. We start off each day early, photographing the sunrise from distinct locations while enjoying hot coffee and breakfast on the go. Our puma tracking team, already hard at work, will be in radio contact to let us know how they’re doing. We begin our wildlife exploration close to EcoCamp, in the park’s eastern sector, making the most of the beautiful morning light and animal activity. We enjoy around six hours of wildlife observation, studying and photographing the park’s native flora & fauna mbefore heading back to EcoCamp for lunch and relaxation time. In the afternoons, after the peak sun hours with little animal movement, we head out again, this time to the park’s western sector where we enjoy the beautiful landscapes and flora & fauna to be found. We visit landmark places such as Grey Glacier and other striking natural monuments. Our guide takes us through the different habitats and ecosystems in the area, introducing us to the unique and colourful wildlife of Torres del Paine. Our tracking team will alert us to any interesting fauna sightings in the area. After photographing the iconic Patagonian sunset over the Paine massif we return to EcoCamp for dinner and well-earned rest. N.B. In the event of bad weather alternative activities will be planned, for example to scenic waterfall Paine Grande or Laguna Azul. (4 x B,L,D)

Sunrise photography session and final lunch before returning to the airport. Today we enjoy our morning sunrise photography session and wildlife exploration in the park’s eastern sector before returning to EcoCamp for lunch. We load our luggage into the van and say goodbye to EcoCamp’s staff as we drive back alongside the Patagonian pampa to the airport to catch our onward flight. (B,L)

tourName: Rio Futaleufu rafting holiday in Chile
placesVisited: White water rafting on Futaleufu River, Inflatable kayaking on Rio Azul, Atmospheric towns: Chaiten and Puerto Varas, Al fresco candle-lit meals, Comfortable camp: saunas, massage, hot tubs, Options for swimming, fishing, mountain biking, horse riding and hiking, Optional tours to Lago Todos los Santos and Saltos de Petrohue (extra cost)
generalInfo:
The Rio Futaleufu runs from Argentina's Los Alerces National Park west through Chile to the atmospheric coastal fishing town of Chaiten. Its clear untamed waters race through a pristine wildnerness of snow capped volcanoes, deep canyons and rich rain forest.

Begin your journey into Patagonia in the beautiful town of Puerto Varas, a distinctive place of wooden houses built by German immigrants by the shores of Lago Llanquihue, Chile’s second-largest lake. From here, transfer by small plane over stunning landscapes to Chaiten to drive to your base camp, taking in the multiple hanging glaciers, jagged glaciated peaks and temperate rainforests that ring Lago Yelcho.

Your white water adventures on the Futaleufu offer variety and unforgettable experiences each day. Adrenaline peaks include the stomping continuous maelstrom known as Mas o Menos (More or Less) and the class V rapid Casa de Piedra (House of Rock), while hardcore rafters can pit themselves against the intense white waters of the Inferno canyon – think aggressive class V paddling. Here too are Class V+ rapids like Zeta and the Throne Room best viewed from riverside!

A day on the Rio Azul uses inflatable kayaks to carve through one of the region's most scenic canyons with a mix of class II and III rapids plus the Class IV ‘Cheese Grater’. The final day's rafting offers stunning views of Las Tres Monjas peaks, as well as two of the trip's toughest rapids - The Terminator plus the haystack wave train known as The Himalayas. Alongside the white water battles, there are hours spent drifting down calm river stretches too.

There are brilliant activities from the base camp too. Take a two-hour horseback ride to a beautiful beach on the Rio Azul for an authentic Patagonian barbecue picnic lunch or a short hike to the 300ft Cascada waterfall. Other options include fly-fishing, mountain biking, yoga, sauna, massage and hiking - or just soak in the hot tub beneath vast Patagonian skies. The hardy can even go for a bracing dip in the river! Each night there are candle-lit al fresco dinners using local produce, plus music and dancing - if your tired limbs are up to it!

dayInfo.description: Arrive Puerto Montt, take a taxi (not included) in to Puerto Varas hotel, dinner (D) Arrive in Santiago, Chile. Collect your luggage, pass through Customs and then re-check in for your domestic flight to Puerto Montt: gate way to Patagonia. Please look for a taxi (not included) to take you the 30 minutes to the beautiful town of Puerto Varas, located on the shores of Lago Llanquihue, which is Chile’s second-largest lake. You may get stunning views of Volcano Osorno, weather permitting. Enjoy strolling the streets, famous for its wooden homes built by German immigrants. Depending on your arrival time, rafting, fishing, or a tour to Lago Todos los Santos and Saltos de Petrohue can be arranged. (not included in trip price) We will meet at 19.00 in the hotel lobby bar for introductions and a welcome briefing. This is followed by a group welcome dinner at one of our favorite restaurants where you can indulge in a steak off the parilla, or try Chile’s famous seafood. Overnight in the lovely Cabanas del Lago Hotel right on the lake. (D)

Transfer to airport, fly to Chaiten, drive to Futaleufu camp and cabana (B,L,D) After breakfast we will board our private vehicle for a 20-minute drive to the La Paloma Airport, where we board our plane for one of the most scenic flights imaginable. After as 30-minute flight, we arrive at Chaiten, a small fishing village and a gateway to Patagonia. Here you will get an immediate sense of wild and scenic Patagonia. Depending on time, we may take a short hike in Pumalin National Park; one of the largest and most diverse conservation efforts in South America. The 715,000-acre Pumalín ark is located in the Palena Province of Chile, and stretches from the heart of the Andes to the fjords of the Pacific Coast. During our two-hour drive to Bio Bio basecamp, we pass the beautiful Lago Yelcho with its multiple hanging glaciers, jagged glaciated peaks, and temperate rainforests. Arrive at the Bio Bio Base Camp, where your private tent bungalows, sitting upon raised platforms and complete with river views and comfortable beds, will be waiting for you.

Safety talk, white water rafting (B,L,D) Awaken on the banks of the Fu and enjoy your first morning in camp. You can take an early morning hike in the valley, or for those who choose to sleep in, rise later with the warmth of the sun and have breakfast around 9am. A pre-breakfast yoga class is available on our customized yoga platform with river views or in the indoor Yoga Loft if the weather is inclement. Mornings tend to be crisp and dewy so prepare to dress warmly - a fleece is perfect. Today is a river day. We will launch our rafts from basecamp after a thorough safety briefing. In a safe ‘eddy’, a short distance downstream, we’ll do a set of practice rescue drills. This allows the crew in each raft to hone their skills and prepare to raft as a team. We use a cataraft combined with ace safety-kayakers as part of our safety net. Each raft is captained by a highly trained and intuitive river guide, who guides the boat from a stern-mounted oar frame. Guiding with oars does not detract from the paddling experience. The advantage to the oar frame is greater control in pointing the bow straight through bus size holes and 15-foot high “haystack” wave trains. High siding is also an actively used paddle command. This style is consistent with any high volume, strong-current river where rapids graded 4 to 5-plus rage on. This is the Futaleufu! The first section that we raft, from camp down to Puente Futaleufu (the Futaleufu Bridge), is only 10km, but offers more rapids per 1,000m than anywhere else on the river. It is the perfect warm up run and it is non-stop fun. The rapids of note are El Cojin (The Cushion), and Mundaca, a local family’s name. At take-out, we meet our vehicles for a 20-minute ride back to camp. Those who would prefer a lower body workout to complement their paddling are welcome to run back or ride one of our mountain bikes from take-out to camp. When we get to camp, you can choose to go fly-fishing, try out a kayak, practice yoga, nap in a hammock, enjoy the sauna, have a massage, go for a hike, or soak in the hot tub. Taking a hot shower, either indoors or under the big sky, feels very luxurious while camping in the remote wilderness of northern Patagonia Of course, for the hardy, the river provides a cold bath and refreshing swim. As the sun sinks behind the mountains, enjoy a game of chess or cards at the sunset bar. Every late afternoon is Happy Hour with an open bar stocked with beer, wine, soda, and fresh juice. Then, we gather together in the open-air kitchen/dining area, the Galpon, for a candlelight sit-down dinner featuring fresh produce, grown right in our own garden, and freshly baked breads. After dinner, enjoy the campfire and the stars before retiring to your cozy tent on your private platform. The sound of the river will lull you to sleep and send you off dreaming of the next day of adventure in Chile.

Rafting to Casa de Piedra (B,L,D) Officially day two of our rafting extravaganza. Our aim is to settle into a river rhythm that will be utilized in order to successfully raft the next few sections the Fu. After Yoga and breakfast, we launch our rafts from camp and have lunch on the river. After we pass the Puente Futaleufu (yesterday’s take-out), we immediately round the corner to meet a big stomping continuous cascade of waves known as Mas o Menos, translated, More or Less. This is a good stepping-stone towards our first true blue class V technical rapid, Casa de Piedra (House of Rock) which is right around the next corner. We get out of our rafts to scout this massive, boulder-choked rapid from the banks of the Fu. It is formed like a series of water wheels that channel all of their fury into a final churning pit with a dragon’s back highway through it; that is, if you hit it on line. After this rapid, we run the remaining class 3 and 4 rapids as our hearts resume beating at their normal rates. We drift into a nice long, calm section that offers perfect fishing from the rafts as well as a great place to get into some hard shell kayaks. The next three miles we have a floating happy hour and reach our take out spot just above Lago Yelcho. Upon return to camp, we continue to celebrate the day, enjoy the spa and get ready for another fabulous dinner prepared by our jovial crew and talented chef.

Inflatable kayak training, Rio Azul (B,L,D) Today we become experts at navigating our very own river crafts, known inflatable kayaks, IK’s or duckies. We venture up canyon to the Rio Azul, one of the main tributaries to the Futaleufu and is one of the most scenic canyons in Patagonia Challenge yourself on the class II and III rapids and depending on your comfort level, either walk or take-on the Class IV rapid, ‘Cheese Grater’. There is something deeply satisfying paddling your own boat down river, knowing that your destiny is in your own hands. Of course our highly trained guides will be there to coach you, watch over you and provide safety should you need to be rescued. Fishing, mountain biking or relaxing around camp are always options in the late afternoon.

Free day, optional fishing, treks, horse back riding (B,L,D) With a range of activities on offer today you will have the chance to explore more of this stunning part of the world. Below the horse ride details: After yoga and breakfast we take a short drive to the stables where we find our trusty steeds saddled up and ready for adventurous riding. After a safety briefing, we ride alongside some local expert equestrians and our own river guides who gladly join the posse up a glorious, pristine side valley where the Rio Azul flows unhindered from its glacial headwaters. We ride about 2 hours to a beautiful beach on the Rio Azul and enjoy an authentic Patagonian Asado picnic lunch. Then you have the chance to take a 30 minute, round-trip, hike to the 300ft Cascada waterfall, one of the most beautiful waterfalls in the country. After relaxing and a short siesta, you have the chance to trot or gallop back to camp. This is a full day and you will be glad to return to camp, enjoy the soothing hot tub, a cold beer or glass of wine as you wait your turn to get a well deserved massage!

Drive to Futaleufu, raft Inferno Canyon (B,L,D) We have an early breakfast in camp then travel 25 kilometres up the road to Rio Espolon to launch our rafts for the Inferno Canyon day. On the Rio Espolon we have a chance to warm up on this low volume river before it joins and helps form the mighty Futaleufu as it gets squeezed into the narrow Inferno canyon. This upper canyon requires aggressive class V paddling and is potentially the most intense section of white water on the river. Many other options exist for those who choose not to participate in Inferno Canyon. Five distinct rapids form a narrow sinuous river passage creating a wet surge and a full on adrenaline rush. The fourth rapid was until recently the smallest of the 5, but due to road building debris landing in the river, has now become nearly impassable at most water levels and requires a walk around and lining the rafts through it. As we come out of Exit, the last rapid, we enter into a long calm. The current remains swift and we cruise many miles downstream arriving at the mandatory portage around the fierce Zeta rapid. We have lunch on the rocks as the crew ghost boats the rafts through this treacherous rapid. After lunch, our first obstacle is Throne Room, a class V+ rapid for kayaks, a ghost boat rapid for rafts. By walking around this rapid, we get a great bird’s eye view of an almost ‘river wide’ hole that could destroy a raft. Back on board our rafts, we are dealt a Royal Flush; a continuous class IV corridor of rapids does not let up until we get to our take-out spot at the Rio Azul footbridge. The rafts are left for the night, tethered on shore. Early evening is spent in camp getting ready for the evening festivities. Blanca and her partner Umberto, locals from a nearby farm, prepare a very special treat for us. They prepare a delicious dinner called Curanto that is typical of the south of Chile and the island of Chiloe. We spend the evening by the bonfire on the beach singing and dancing the night away.

White water rafting Terminator, Kyburz and Himalayas, farewell BBQ (B,L,D) Today, we must be mentally and physically well prepared for the river. We call it the summit day as we aim to top our already great paddling days with the best day of white water in the world. After a nutritious breakfast, we head up river to the footbridge where we left the rafts yesterday. As our day on the river begins, the blue glacial run-off from the Rio Azul River merges into the Fu from the right. The views of the snow-capped mountain peaks and jagged ridges of the mountain Las Tres Monjas (translated, the three Nuns) are absolutely breathtaking. A six-kilometre stretch of warm-up rapids leads us to the longest and toughest rapid that we will raft, The Terminator. We scout and study our line, then we take the plunge and drop in. “Left turn, right turn, dig it in — hard forward!” are a few of the commands that might be heard. The next three miles are non-stop rapids. After an aerobic workout, we pump through the enormous haystack wave train known as the Himalayas. Just when we need it, a calm returns, we float gently into lunch, served at our base camp. After lunch, we return to the river to complete the last task for the day, tackling as much white water as possible. We raft the whole section of river from camp to below Casa de Piedra. At take-out, cold beers and tea are waiting. We make a triumphant return to camp to celebrate our days spent exploring Futaleufu valley and river. For the evening’s festivities, Rolando and Nelli will prepare a typical Chilean Asado — lamb roasted over a bed of coals, ensalada, potatoes and farm fresh bread. We toast the river and give thanks for our safe passage. Under a bright starry sky, we will spend our last night together as a group on the banks of the mighty Fu with the guides and crew.

AM transfer to Chaiten airport, fly to Puerto Montt, end of services (B) We start early today as we have to travel back down to the coast to catch the puddle jumper flight from Chaiten back to Puerto Montt for connecting flights either home or to your next destination. You need to leave a comfortable “window” to make it back in time, so book connecting flights that leave Puerto Montt 14:00hrs onwards. You may also choose to spend another night in Puerto Varas on your own (ask for extension options). We hope that when you board the airplane you will look back upon your time in Patagonia and think of the friends you have made and the beauty of the Futaleufu River and Patagonian wilderness. Ciao amigos!

tourName: Sea kayaking tour in Northern Patagonia
generalInfo:
Embark on an unforgettable 4-day sea kayaking adventure in the stunning Pumalín National Park, a vast conservation area in Chile’s Los Lagos and Aysén regions. Established in 2018 by conservationist Douglas Tompkins, the park was created to preserve the breath-taking wilderness of northern Patagonia.

This guided, self-supported kayak expedition takes you through the heart of the park along the turquoise waters of the Comau Fjord, offering unparalleled views of the richly biodiverse Valdivian temperate rainforest, cascading waterfalls, and lush coastal landscapes.

As you paddle, you’ll be immersed in a vibrant ecosystem. Overhead, you might spot cormorants, kelp gulls, southern lapwings, buzzard eagles, and chimango caracaras soaring through the sky. The waters are home to playful sea otters, sleek dolphins, and majestic sea lions, while the coastal forests shelter elusive species such as foxes, the rare pudú deer, huemul, and even the occasional puma.

The Valdivian rainforest pulses with life. Listen for the rhythmic drumming of the Magellanic woodpecker, the croaks of frogs, and the sharp calls of the Chucao Tapaculo, a small bird often seen hopping in the lower branches. Keep an eye out for the dazzling Green-backed Firecrown hummingbird, which flits at the forest's edge in search of nectar.

This expedition offers a unique opportunity to connect with the pristine beauty of Patagonia, combining adventure and wildlife exploration in one of Chile's most remarkable national parks.

dayInfo.description: Pick up from airport/hotel in Puerto Montt, drive to Puerto Varas, (B) On your arrival at the airport or hotel in Puerto Montt, you will be met and transferred to your accommodation in Puerto Varas. Puerto Varas, a charming town with strong German colonial heritage, was established in the 1850s by German immigrants. Situated on the shores of Lake Llanquihue, the town offers stunning scenery, sandy beaches, and an array of water sports, including rowing, sailing, and swimming. Take time to explore the town’s distinctive German-style architecture, characterized by houses of hard-wearing, water-resistant Alerce Andino wood. Don’t miss the Sacred Heart of Jesus Church, an iconic landmark built between 1915 and 1918, located on a hill in the town center

First day of Kayak, (B,L,D) Your adventure starts today! After an early pickup from your hotel in Puerto Varas, we travel to Hornopirén and cross to Llancahue Island. Following a hearty lunch, we spend 2-3 hours practicing sea kayaking, familiarizing ourselves with the equipment, and preparing for the days ahead. The day concludes with loading the kayaks for tomorrow, relaxing in the hotel’s thermal pools, and enjoying a pisco sour and a delicious dinner. Distance: 10 km kayaking Accommodation: Simple hotel

Full day Kayak (B,L,D) After breakfast, we set off on our kayaking journey early so we beat the midday winds. Today’s route takes us from Llancahue Island southeast to Quintupeu Fjord. Marvel at the dramatic cliffs where the Andes meet the Pacific Ocean. After a beachside lunch—with the option to shower under a waterfall—we continue paddling to the end of the fjord’, where we set up camp and prepare dinner. Then it’s time to rest up for the next day’s adventure! Distance: 20-25 km kayaking Accommodation: Camping

Full day kayak, camp (B,L,D) We start before sunrise to make the most of favourable tidal conditions on the most challenging day of the trip. With snacks on hand, we paddle into Cahuelmó Fjord, timing our entry to avoid strong winds and take advantage of the tidal flow. When we reach Cahuelmó River and the famous hot springs, we’ll have time to relax our muscles before setting up camp in a forested area and enjoying dinner. Distance: 20-25 km kayaking Accommodation: Camping

Final day Kayak, return Puerto Varas (B,L) Following breakfast and a last visit to the hot springs, we pack up and paddle towards a nearby sea lion colony. At the mouth of the estuary, we meet the support boat to load the kayaks before heading back to Hornopirén for lunch in the village. The journey concludes with a transfer back to Puerto Varas, where we arrive around 7:00 PM. Distance: 10 km kayaking Accommodation: Hotel in Puerto Varas
Tour Ends, or add walking, cycling. (B) Our tour concludes today. You can either depart or extend your adventure with additional walking or cycling excursions.

tourName: Self drive Patagonia holiday including Mapuche culture
placesVisited: Summit Villarrica and Sollipulli volcanoes, Rainforest hiking with guide and pack horse, Overnight in traditional Mapuche ‘ruka’, Conguillio National Park, Araucarias forest and Huerquehue National Park, Villarrica National park, Chiloe National Park, Car rental, Homestays
generalInfo:
This 18 day tailor made, self drive Patagonia holiday comes with a car rental so that you can take off and enjoy the vast wilderness wonders at your own pace, but following our carefully crafted itinerary. This holiday will not only take you through our snow-capped volcanoes, up to exquisite, elevated lakes and Araucaria forests, and down to coastal villages but also to meet with indigenous Mapuche communities along the way.

Patagonia is the ancestral home of the indigenous Mapuche people, who have lived on this land for centuries. Land is sacred to these people, and indeed they are known as ‘people of the land’ locally because their connection with nature and the environment is innate. by spending time in Mapuche communities on this trip you will be able to learn about Patagonian culture and nature. You will even get a chance to spend a night with a local Mapuche family in their “ruka”, a traditional wooden house.

During this holiday, we highly recommend visits to four of our most magnificent national parks: Conguillio, Huerquehue, Villarrica and Chiloe with plenty of time built in for you to enjoy some outdoor exploration. In Conguilio the "Los nevados " hike with views over to Lake and Volcano Llaima is breathtaking. In Huerquehue you will be astounded by the sacred and stunning Araucarias forests, climb up Villarrica volcano and then bliss out among the marine wildlife on Chiloe Island where penguins, sea lions, Commerson’s dolphins and pelicans are just a few of the treats in store.

Please note that this is just a suggested itinerary below, and as this is a tailor made trip we are happy to adjust it to suit your interests and travel requirements. We will also provide you with our bespoke road book with all the information necessary for the smooth running of your stay, as well as a mobile phone to be in contact with us 24/7.

dayInfo.description: Your rental car will be waiting for you at Temuco Airport, located in Chile's Lake District, at the gateway to Patagonia. From there, you'll drive to the coast, to meet with your guide from the local Mapuche community. On the banks of the Queule river, you will experience the rich Lafkenche culture, where spirituality and hospitality blend with activities such as bird watching, boat rides, and traditional Mapuche storytelling, filled with legends and mythology. Additionally, you will have the option of spending the night with a local family or a B&B. >Transport: rental car - 1h45 > Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: none

Today you will explore the area with Victoria, an expert on the local bird population. She has her own boat to take you to the best places for bird watching, depending on the weather and the time of year. > Transport: rental car - 1h > Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: breakfast & dinner

It's time to say goodbye to Victoria and head east to Melipeuco. Here, you can explore breathtaking landscapes that include volcanoes, araucarias, lakes, and waterfalls. > Transport: rental car – 170km - 2h30 > Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: breakfast.

Visit the National Park of Conguillio, located about 30 minutes from Melipeuco. After crossing several black lava flows, you will arrive to the starting point of a walk "Los nevados " that will lead you to astonishing views of the Lake and Volcano Llaima. This walk is also an opportunity to discover several types of endemic plants species and a large variety of birds. >Transport: rental car – 50km - 1h > Accommodation: family run hotel > Included meals: breakfast > Entrance to the park not included

Today you will drive to meet the next local community in Kurarewe. In Mapuzugun (Mapuche language), Kurarewe means "altar of stone." Upon arrival, you will be welcomed and guided through a traditional garden, where your host is a seed guardian. You will then explore a rural farm and learn about daily life and activities. The guide will then accompany you to the host family’s home, where you will have dinner and stay overnight. > Transport: rental car – 155km - 3h > Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: breakfast and dinner

The second day begins with an interpretive trail through an araucaria forest in Villarrica National Park. During the walk, the guide will engage in conversation with the visitors; you’ll have the opportunity to ask questions and enjoy a lively dialogue throughout the trek. At midday, you’ll have lunch and savor dishes from Mapuche and rural cuisine. In the afternoon, there will be a cooking workshop where you’ll prepare a traditional rural tea, which you’ll later enjoy, marking the end of the day. Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: breakfast and dinner

The day begins with a talk on ancestral games. Here, the guide will share their knowledge about the games, and you’ll get to see some of the elements used in these games. Afterward, you’ll visit a traditional weaving workshop where you can observe different looms and their uses, learn about the wool-working process, and explore various colors and textures. At midday, you’ll enjoy a lunch featuring traditional Mapuche and rural cuisine. In the afternoon, there will be a short interpretive walk, followed by a talk on Mapuche territory and philosophy. > Accommodation: Homestay > Included meals: breakfast and dinner

Today you will drive south to the lakeshore town of Puerto Octay, a charming town with a beautiful German-style architecture. We also recommend visiting the town of Frutillar. We recommend staying at the local Hotel, part of the architectural heritage of Puerto Octay. Alternatively, you could spend an extra night between stops, as the area is dotted with stunning lakes. > Transport: rental car - 350 km 4h > Accommodation: Hotel > Included meals: breakfast

Drive to Petrehue and embark on a boat to reach El Rincon across Lake Todos Los Santos. Here begins your hike to the Callao refuge. You will go through millennial native rainforests and hilly meadows before reaching the refuge. This is a great place to disconnect and relax This wooden basic retreat offers a unique experience with its wood-fired kitchen and larch wood hot tubs, surrounded by forests and mountains, in Vicente Pérez Rosales N. Park. > Transport : rental car – 75km - 1h + dinghy - 1h> Accommodation: rural refuge > Included meals: breakfast and dinner. > Trekking : 4h30 easy hike or 2h horseback

Today you will enjoy the surrounding area with some short hikes and hot tub. Rudi and his son will prepare a traditional meal cooked over an open fire for you. Overnight in the refuge. > Accommodation: rural refuge> Included meals: breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Time to head back to civilisation, but just for a short while. First, you’ll head back to Petrehue. From there, drive south all the way to Caleta Puelche from where you will board the ferry. You will drive through the Cochamó Valley, also known as the "Yosemite of South America, characterized by wetlands, Andean glaciers, vast forests, and towering granite mountains. > Transport : rental car – 150km - 4h + dinghy - 1h> Accommodation: hotel > Included meals: breakfast > Trekking : 4h30 easy hike or 2h horseback

Today we recommend you visit the Alerce Andino National Park. Here you could visit the ancient Alerce (Fitzroya) trees in the Sargazo sector of the park––which are around 2,500 years old––or in the Las Chaicas sector of the park, where they’re nearly 3,000 years old. > Transport: rental car > Accommodation: Hotel > Included meals: breakfast > Trekking : depending on itinerary

Time to leave the mainland and drive to Chiloé Island. You will cross the Chacao channel with a 45-minute ferry ride. The fiords and natural bays of this archipelago were all carved by ancient glacial action. Spend the next two days in the north of the Island, along the Pacific coast to appreciate marine life.. > Transport: rental car – 130km + ferry - 3h30 > Accommodation: hotel > Included meals: breakfast

Today the fishermen of Puñihuil will guide you through some local marine life including penguins, sea lions, dolphins, sea otters, pelicans and a variety of other seabirds. These fishermen, aware of the negative impact of fishing on biodiversity have created an association for the protection and development of natural heritage through tourism as a new source of income. > Accommodation: Hotel > Included meals: breakfast

Head for Chiloé National Park in the morning, discover the virgin forest along the wild Pacific coast. You may have a chance to meet the miners who settled on the coast during the gold mining days… > Transport: rental car – 58km - 1h > Accommodation: hotel > Included meals: breakfast

Enjoy a day of leisure back in Castro. We will recommend some artisans and associations so you can immerse yourself in the local culture. Maria Elena will welcome you in the evening with a good dinner. > Transport: rental car – 58km - 1h > Accommodation: host family > Included meals: breakfast and dinner
Enjoy a hearty farmer breakfast before heading to Puerto Montt’s airport. Return your rental car. > Transport: rental car – 130km + ferry - 3h30 > Included meals: breakfast

tourName: Small group tours to Chile
placesVisited: Santiago, Valparaiso, San Pedro de Atacama, Atacama Desert, Puerto Varas, Petrohue Falls, Lake Todos los Santos, Chiloe Islands, Punta Arenas, Tierra del Fuego, Torres del Paine National Park, Lago Gray Glacier
generalInfo:
City, lakes, islands and glaciers – this small group holiday to Chile captures practically every angle of the country’s south in two weeks. You’ll start off in the twin cities of Santiago and Valparaiso. The former is all colonial architecture and panoramic parks; the latter is a hilly sea port. It’d be rude not to pop by the Chilean vineyards outside Santiago, too.

Outside the cities, you’ll delve into the Atacama desert and bright turquoise Lake Miscanti. You’ll get a few nights in Torres del Paine National Park, too – the poster child of Chile’s glacier-carved south.

Chile is a country of epic proportions, so expect a few domestic flights and road trips thrown in along the way – along with boat trips that take you towards sky-scraping monoliths like Glacier Grey.

dayInfo.title: Walking tour of the colonial centre.
dayInfo.description: In the afternoon your guided city tour takes you to all the major sites of this fascinating city concentrating on Santiago’s bustling historic centre, which in recent years has taken on a new lease of life. Awakening from years of neglect, the traditional residential neighbourhood of Lastarria is a delight to explore, replete with shops, arty cafés and characterful hotels. Nearby, leafy Parque Forestal was inaugurated in the early twentieth century to celebrate the first 100 years of the republic. It is just a few blocks from the beating heart of old Santiago, the Plaza de Armas, the capital’s main square which is graced by elegant Chilean wine palms with their characteristic bottle-shaped trunks. Grouped around the plaza are Santiago’s Cathedral, the main post office, the National Historic Museum and the Municipalidad de Santiago (city hall). From here, if time, visit San Cristóbal Hill by riding the cable car to the top. On clear days there are spectacular panoramic views across the city towards the Andes.

dayInfo.title: Optional visits to Pacific port Valparaiso or nearby vineyard.
dayInfo.description: Today there is an optional visit to Chile’s second city, Valparaíso (2 hrs by bus). This lively seaport is built on a series of hills which form a backdrop to the wide bay, with views over the seaside resort of Viña del Mar. You can wander through the steep, winding streets and among the brightly-coloured colonial homes built for 19th century British and German merchants, or take a ride in one of the creaky wooden funiculars which link the cliff-top communities. Time permitting, you may wish to visit one of the vineyards close to Santiago, to sample some highly respected Chilean wine.

dayInfo.title: Fly north to San Pedro
dayInfo.description: Fly north to Calama (2 hours) where you will be driven (90mins) to the oasis of San Pedro de Atacama. San Pedro is a timeless adobe town with a laid back atmosphere and an erratic electricity supply. Its dusty streets are lined with bars, cafés and tour operators offering various excursions into the surrounding desert. On the guided excursion you arrive late in the afternoon at the Moon Valley (its name tells it all) to explore shady gorges and canyons formed over centuries by the erosion of salt mountains. Just before dusk, climb to the ridge of a vast golden sand dune to see the landscape lit up in different shades of pink, crimson and mandarin cast by the setting sun.

dayInfo.title: Explore the Atacama desert.
dayInfo.description: Explore the region’s other-worldly landscape on a full day excursion to the Atacama salt flats and surrounding lakes. Across the dazzling, pitted surface of the salar, you’ll see pink-tinged flamingos feeding, reflected in the glimmering pools. A dusty drive takes you through some tiny hamlets where Atacameños eke out a living in these harsh conditions, before continuing to Lakes Miscanti and Miñiques. Here you’re left literally breathless – at over 4,000m the air is thin and cold. Take a walk around the lakeshore and picnic with a view of the volcanic cones perfectly reflected in the turquoise waters.

dayInfo.title: Optional excursions around San Pedro.
dayInfo.description: Should you choose to take the morning optional excursion to El Tatio Geysers, be prepared for a very early start. But it’s well worth it. You arrive on the pitted, craggy geyser field just before dawn, and as the sun rises and warms the earth, hot steam projects dramatically out of the crater into the freezing morning air, creating a wall of mist through which you can make out dark silhouettes against the penetrating sunlight. Alternatively you may want to walk to Pukará de Quitor (3 km). This old Inca fortress has superb views of the mountains and volcanoes bordering Bolivia and Argentina.

dayInfo.title: Fly via Santiago to the lake district and waterside Puerto Varas.
dayInfo.description: Fly south via Santiago to Puerto Montt, and continue by road to Puerto Varas, situated on the shores of Lake Llanquihue (one of the largest natural lakes in South America), in the heart of the lake district. Towering snow-capped volcanoes punctuate a patchwork landscape of cultivated hills and pastures. The town sits in the shadows of the perfect conical peak of the Osorno and Calbuco volcanoes. Originally colonised by German immigrants, it has a distinctive, Bavarian feel. There are some excellent seafood restaurants and cafés serving creamy küchen to while away your free time.

dayInfo.title: Excursion to Petrohué Falls; boat trip on Lake Todos Los Santos.
dayInfo.description: Today you will visit the Petrohué Falls where you stand on wooden walkways and gaze down in to the glacial turquoise waters. Follow the trails through the forest and along the shores of Lake Todos los Santos, where you will take a boat trip on the gem-clear, emerald green waters. On a clear day, this is some of the most exquisite scenery on the continent.

dayInfo.title: Optional full-day visit to Chiloé Island.
dayInfo.description: We strongly recommend a full-day excursion to Chiloé. This extraordinary island developed largely independently from the mainland and has a distinct history, architecture and mythology. Alighting on its shores is like stepping back into a time of mists and legends. Half the population works in agriculture, the techniques of which have remained unchanged for centuries; distinctive ox-driven carts are to be seen trundling down the island’s unpaved roads past unique wood-shingled churches and there are several folksy fishing ports where you can savour fresh oysters. November-March you can take a boat trip to spot Magellanic and Humboldt penguins. The excursion ends with a visit to a chilote family, where the traditional curanto is prepared for you; it’s a hearty dish of seafood, meat, potatoes and vegetables are piled high in a hole in the ground, buried and cooked among glowing embers.

dayInfo.title: Fly south to Puerto Natales in Patagonia.
dayInfo.description: After a short drive to Puerto Montt, a 2 hour flight takes you south to Puerto Natales (Punta Arenas Airport is used if flight schedules are not available). On a clear day you have views of the southern icecap, its fjords, volcanoes and glaciers. Your luxury hotel is just outside Puerto Natales on the shores of Last Hope Sound, a short drive from Torres del Paine National Park. It gets its inspiration from (and retains parts of) the original abandoned structure of an early 20th century refrigeration plant, built in what is now called Post-Victorian Industrial style.

dayInfo.title: Explore the national park on some of the included excursions.
dayInfo.description: For 2 full days the group will explore the Torres del Paine National Park by private vehicle and on foot, leaving in the morning and returning to the comfort of Puerto Natales by evening. We include the famous boat trip that navigates towards the wall of giant Glacier Grey. The boat will set a course through the vivid blue icebergs that crowd Lago Grey before taking you right up to the face of the enormous glacier. This is a monumental ice field extending almost as far as the eye can see and fronted by a cracking, calving wall of azure pinnacles. Whilst exploring the park they’ll be stops to visit some of the best viewpoints such as Lago Nordenskjold and Salto Grande. The scenery is overwhelming; the granite massif of the Cuernos, milky lakes dotted with icebergs and, soaring above, condors riding against perpetual fierce winds. Spend the rest of your days exploring the national park on foot. Follow a number of different walking trails winding alongside the glacial lakes and rivers with close-up views of tortured rock towers and needles rising 3,000m into a tempestuous sky. The difficulty and length of the available walks in the park vary hugely, and some may not be suitable for all passengers.

dayInfo.title: By road to Punta Arenas
dayInfo.description: Journey back south to Punta Arenas, once an important, British-influenced trading centre before the opening of the Panama Canal turned it into a backwater; the region’s fortunes were only briefly revived during a short-lived gold rush. To add to its woes, the sheep-rearing business has never recovered from the catastrophic collapse of the price of meat and wool. It’s now a gateway to Chilean Patagonia and the nearby National parks.

dayInfo.title: Continue to Punta Arenas and fly back to Santiago.
dayInfo.description: Catch a flight back to Santiago (4 hours) which normally includes a stop in Puerto Montt where those wishing to continue with the lake crossing to Argentina will leave the group. Overnight in the capital.

tourName: Southern Chile holiday, Lake District and Patagonia
generalInfo:
From smoldering volcanoes and timeless forests to glacier-carved mountains, ice fields, and wind-swept plains, southern Chile is a wonderland of unbelievable landscapes that have drawn people from all over the world for centuries, turning it into a cultural melting pot. On this 12-day tour, you’ll travel from the idyllic wilds of the Lakes District to the rugged expanses of southern Patagonia, encountering incredible nature, outdoor adventure, local wildlife, and cultural and culinary experiences that are wholly unique to this region of the world.

Starting in the bustling cosmopolitan capital of Santiago with a foodie tour to introduce you to Chile’s diverse cuisine, you’ll then head south of the Lakes District, staying in the picturesque town of Puerto Varas, which is famous for its traditional Germanic houses and culture. Over the next few days, you’ll discover the astonishing landscapes and biodiversity of the region, climbing snow-capped volcanoes, visiting the mystical islands of the Chiloé archipelago, hiking through temperate rainforests once explored by Darwin, and learning about the culture and traditions of the Huilliche people, a local indigenous tribe.

Next stop is the very tip of the continent, Patagonia. After a short stop in Punta Arenas to visit a penguin colony, you’ll head to the crown jewel of Chile’s national parks system, Torres del Paine, where visitors are wowed by the breathtaking mountains of the Paine Massif, the Grey Glacier, and local wildlife like pumas and guanacos. Here, you’ll immerse yourself in the best the region has to offer, like hiking the park’s most iconic treks, trying local foods, kayaking along wild fjords, and visiting a traditional sheep-herding estancia. The trip will then finish back in Santiago.

If you are looking for adventure and wonder in a place unlike anywhere you’ve ever been, come to Patagonia. It’s waiting for you.
